meanings.definition: To make something legally or officially void or ineffective.
meanings.sent1: The judge had to invalidate the contract due to missing signatures.
meanings.sent2: The new evidence will invalidate the previous ruling.
meanings.sent3: The magician's trick was to invalidate the contract by tearing it up.
meanings.sent4: The storm's damage seemed to invalidate any hope of repair.
meanings.sent5: The teacher's red pen seemed to invalidate every mistake on the test.

meanings.definition: To show that something is false or incorrect.
meanings.sent1: The scientist's experiment results could invalidate the theory.
meanings.sent2: The witness testimony may invalidate the defendant's alibi.
meanings.sent3: The detective's findings seemed to invalidate the suspect's story.
meanings.sent4: The broken compass would invalidate any sense of direction.
meanings.sent5: The faulty map seemed to invalidate every attempt to navigate the forest.

meanings.definition: To weaken or destroy the validity of something.
meanings.sent1: The virus could potentially invalidate the vaccine's effectiveness.
meanings.sent2: The constant criticism began to invalidate her self-confidence.
meanings.sent3: The rain threatened to invalidate the ink on the document.
meanings.sent4: The relentless waves seemed to invalidate the sandcastle's stability.
meanings.sent5: The faulty foundation would invalidate any hope of a sturdy house.
